citation.article-title: Rothia amarae sp. nov., from sludge of a foul water sewer
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Rothia amarae sp. nov.
Rothia amarae (a'ma.rae. L. adj. amara, -ae of a trench, conduit, referring to fact that the bacterium was isolated from a sewage duct)
Cells are Gram-positive, non-motile cocci, 0.6-0.9 μm in diameter, occurring singly or in pairs, tetrads or packets.
The colonies are creamy, with smooth surfaces in young colonies and rough surfaces in old ones.
Non-pigmented.
Endospores not produced.
Facultatively anaerobic and catalase-positive.
Acid produced from glucose, sucrose, glycerol, maltose, mannose, ribose, salicin and trehalose, but not from lactose, mannitol, raffinose or sorbitol.
Ester lipase C-8 and valine arylamidase are produced.
Trypsin, phosphatase and urease are not produced.
Nitrate is reduced.
Aesculin and gelatin are hydrolysed.
Optimum growth temperature is 30-37°C.
No growth at 15 or 45°C.
The cell wall peptidoglycan is of the Lys-Glu-Ala type (variation A3a).
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylglycerol and diphosphatidylglycerol; phosphatidylinositol is a minor polar lipid.
The major menaquinones are MK-6(H2) and MK-7.
The major cellular fatty acid is ai-C15:0 (72.3% of total), with smaller proportions of ai-C17:0 (10.0%), C16:0 (2.9%), i-C16:0 (5.4%), C15:0 (2.5%), i-C15:0 (5.5%) and i-C14:0 (1.5%).
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 54.5 mol%.
Isolated from a sludge sample taken from a foul water sewer in Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China.
The type strain is strain J18T (=AS 4.1721T=JCM 11375T).
